content: "{\"object\":\"value\",\"document\":{\"object\":\"document\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"image\",\"data\":{\"size\":14889,\"src\":\"https://onboarding.epam.com/app/cdn/4c121dc2-fc3f-4d7e-a7e2-415af9749095/4.PNG?preview=true\",\"path\":\"https://onboarding.epam.com/app/cdn/4c121dc2-fc3f-4d7e-a7e2-415af9749095/4.PNG?preview=true\",\"align\":\"align-center\",\"fileName\":\"4.PNG\",\"name\":\"4.PNG\",\"mimeType\":{\"type\":\"image\",\"subtype\":\"png\",\"parameters\":{},\"qualityValue\":1,\"concrete\":true,\"wildcardType\":false,\"wildcardSubtype\":false,\"charset\":null},\"type\":\"image\",\"id\":\"4c121dc2-fc3f-4d7e-a7e2-415af9749095\",\"imageSize\":{\"width\":1028.9931640625,\"height\":221.21911860447304},\"extension\":\"PNG\"},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-header-4\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"What NOT to Do\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Just as there are things you should do on a project, there are also things you should NOT do. Some of these may go without saying, but we will say them anyways:\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"unordered-list\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"DO NOT Assume. Double and Triple Check\",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\" - Often our assumptions get us into trouble. Assumptions lead us to not clarify, ask or state something we believe to be obvious. However, in the event that it is not obvious or aligned with others, our assumptions can make an ASS out of U and ME. Therefore, do not assume. Always check.\",\"marks\":[]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"DO NOT Leave Areas of Responsibility Ambiguous\",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\" - Without clarity around the areas of responsibility for each role, your run the risk of frustrating your team. When it isn’t clear who is responsible for what, sometimes people do double work, sometimes the work never gets done, and sometime people clash over who they think the work should belong to. If you are setting up a team, make sure their AORs are clear. Try using a RACI.\",\"marks\":[]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"DO NOT Procrastinate\",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\" - Procrastination leaves you vulnerable to unnecessary risks. When you leave your work till the last minute, you are being cruel to yourself. You are using the negative consequences of an approaching deadline to motivate yourself into crammed labor. This is not good for you or your project because you increase the risk of incompletion and the consequences that follow. Be reasonable about what work you have to get done. Plan it out at a realistic pace, and discipline yourself to get it done.\",\"marks\":[]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"DO NOT Expect the Client to Cover for You \",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"- This doesn’t mean to expect the client will throw you under the bus either. It does mean that if you are going to take a risk, make sure you have documented all the decisions and approvals associated with the risk. If things go south on a project, it is better to be prepared for the client to oppose you and learn that they actually support you, than to be prepared for the client to support you and learn that they actually oppose you.\",\"marks\":[]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"DO NOT Consider a Project Too Small to Fail\",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\" - If you neglect your smallest projects or workstreams, they may come back to haunt you. Small projects will likely have small risks, but if you ignore them completely, the risks can grow and cause big problems.\",\"marks\":[]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"DO NOT Let Teams Run Without Supervision\",\"marks\":[{\"object\":\"mark\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-bold\",\"data\":{}}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\" - Once the team has hit the performing phase, we can have the tendency to believe that the bulk of the work is done, and now the team can run in autopilot. This is not so. You must still monitor and control your project and the team. This doesn’t mean micromanage them, but it does mean you need to routinely check-in with them and maintain awareness of what is happening.\",\"marks\":[]}]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Some of these suggestions of what NOT to do come directly from this case study. Check it out to understand in better detail why you shouldn’t do these things:\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"unordered-list\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Case Study – Small Project, Big Mistake: \",\"marks\":[]},{\"object\":\"inline\",\"type\":\"link\",\"data\":{\"url\":\"https://kb.epam.com/display/EPMDMO/Small+project+for+Large+Account\"},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Small project for Large Account - DM Central (DMC) - EPAM Knowledge Base\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"\",\"marks\":[]}]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"uui-richTextEditor-header-4\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Red Projects Case Studies\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"A Red project often means something was not done properly and there is no short cut to fixing the problem. The best way to avoid Red Projects is to call for help early. The earlier you call it out, get help and plan a way forward, the less likely it is that your project will go red.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"One of the best ways to prevent your project from going red is to learn from previous mistakes. Here are a few case studies on projects that went red.\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"unordered-list\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Case Study – Eco Lab: \",\"marks\":[]},{\"object\":\"inline\",\"type\":\"link\",\"data\":{\"url\":\"https://kb.epam.com/display/EPMDMO/Ecolab+TCD+project%3A+Regaining+the+client%27s+trust+and+getting+back+on+track\"},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Ecolab TCD project: Regaining the client's trust and getting back on track - DM Central (DMC) - EPAM Knowledge Base\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"\",\"marks\":[]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Case Study – GE Healthcare: \",\"marks\":[]},{\"object\":\"inline\",\"type\":\"link\",\"data\":{\"url\":\"https://kb.epam.com/display/EPMDMO/E-Commerce+solution+for+GE+Healthcare#ECommercesolutionforGEHealthcare-TheChallenge\"},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"E-Commerce solution for GE Healthcare - DM Central (DMC) - EPAM Knowledge Base\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"\",\"marks\":[]}]}]},{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"block\",\"type\":\"list-item-child\",\"data\":{},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"\",\"marks\":[]},{\"object\":\"inline\",\"type\":\"link\",\"data\":{\"url\":\"https://epam-my.sharepoint.com/:p:/r/personal/brian_murphy_epam_com/Documents/ctc/ctco-orke/reports/Zed%20Deck%20Conference.pptx?d=w77c874e94b3549729ed5d0296157db37&csf=1&web=1&e=ghIYhl\"},\"nodes\":[{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"Zed Deck Conference.pptx\",\"marks\":[]}]},{\"object\":\"text\",\"text\":\"\",\"marks\":[]}]}]}]}]}}"
